posts.cooked: As Signal is a privacy-focused messaging platform, and accepting Monero aligns perfectly with its ethos, why doesn’t Signal accept it?

posts.name: kara
posts.cooked:
Hi @twistablemanicotti , I think the technical reason for this is that the crypto currency donation option on the Signals donation website is powered by thegivingblock. Looking at the list of cryptocurrencies they support, it seems Monero is not supported. So for me it seems that the reason is a technical one, the lack of Monero support in the donation plattform, and not a decission that Signal has made based on ethos or other reasons.
For in-app donations afaik there is not support for crypto currencies at all.

posts.name: kara
posts.cooked:
I also think it would be cool if Signal had Monero support. Of course it is technically not dificult to setup a Monero wallet, but besides the effort of the one-time technical setup there probably would be additional regular task for the Signal team related to bookkeeping, maybe compliance things, and also exchanging Monero to USD. Depending on how many people would donate in Monero it might probably be worth it, but since the team is small they probably don’t see this as a top priority.

Also, from my personal perspective, I don’t really worry about somebody finding out I donate to Signal, although I generally agree that payment privacy is something good to have. Personal threat models differ, of course.

posts.name: Talya (she/her)
posts.cooked:
most charities are not interested in holding cryptocurrency, as those could land them in hot regulatory water. as such, most charities opt for systems that allow them to insta-sell whatever crypto they get, such that they never actually hold any of it. that is the exact offer by The Giving Block, and so i assume that’s why they chose it.
if they wanted to have the same scheme with Monero, they’d have to either find a provider of the same service who handles Monero, or create one themselves, both of which i must assume are less desireable than just sticking to what works.

posts.name: Pickle
posts.cooked: You can always create a throwaway wallet and exchange some of your XMR to BTC. That way you can maintain your privacy and still donate with a currency the Signal team can automatically process.

@rassilon1963,

If Signal isn’t willing or able to hold Monero due to “compliance reasons,” I’d like to see that claim backed up with specifics, rather than it just being stated as a blanket issue. The reality is that there are established services—like NOWPayments (Accept Monero Payments | Crypto Payment Gateway) or CoinPayments (https://www.coinpayments.net/supported-coins) that handle Monero-to-fiat conversions, while also ensuring compliance with relevant regulations. These solutions are designed specifically to take the burden off organizations, letting them accept Monero without holding it or dealing with regulatory headaches themselves.

Let’s also look at the glowing hypocrasy of whats being said here - Bitcoin itself was once labeled a compliance nightmare. People said it would be impossible to integrate into existing systems, citing issues like traceability, volatility, and regulation. Yet, over time, businesses, charities, and even Signal found ways to work around those challenges and accept it. So, if compliance concerns didn’t stop Signal from adding Bitcoin, why should they stop Monero?

Monero is no more a “compliance issue” than Bitcoin once was it’s just newer to the mainstream. Solutions exist that can handle the compliance side of things, and other privacy focused platforms (like Mullvad VPN) are already using these tools successfully. If they can do it, Signal can too.

The claim that “compliance reasons” prevent Signal from accepting Monero feels unsubstantiated without real evidence or an explanation. What’s the actual blocker? If Signal wants to be seen as a leader in privacy first technology, they should openly explore these options or at least explain why they can’t. Accepting Monero would not only respect donors’ privacy but also reinforce Signal’s mission.

pickle_umbrella:

You can always create a throwaway wallet and exchange some of your XMR to BTC. That way you can maintain your privacy and still donate with a currency the Signal team can automatically process.

Convert Monero to Bitcoin? That misses my point entirely. If someone is using Monero, it’s likely because privacy is a core part of their threat model. Asking them to convert it to Bitcoin introduces unnecessary risks that ultimately can cost people more than just a donation… it adds friction. People shouldn’t have to jump through hoops to support Signal. By accepting Monero directly, Signal would make it easier for users to donate privately and uphold the privacy principles it’s built on. Let’s not push the responsibility onto the users when there are straightforward solutions Signal could implement.
